definition[0]: used to encourage someone to do something
example[1]: Come on, you can do it!
definition[1]: used to tell someone that you know that what they have just said was not true or right
definition[2]: used to make someone angry enough to want to fight you
definition[3]: used to tell someone to come in, over, up etc, usually in a friendly way
example[5]: Come on in – I’ve made some coffee.
definition[4]: if a light or machine comes on, it starts working
example[6]: A dog started barking and lights came on in the house.
definition[5]: if an illness comes on, you start to be ill with it
example[7]: I can feel a headache coming on.
definition[6]: if a television or radio programme comes on, it starts
example[8]: Just at that moment, the news came on.
definition[7]: if rain or snow comes on, it starts
example[9]: The rain came on just before lunchtime.
definition[8]: to come onto a stage or sports field
example[10]: He scored only two minutes after he’d come on.
example[11]: The children are really coming on now.
example[12]: Your English is coming on really well.
definition[10]: to find or discover someone or something by chance
example[13]: We came on a group of students having a picnic.
definition[11]: to make it very clear to someone that you think they are sexually attractive
definition[12]: something that someone does deliberately to make someone else sexually interested in them
note[0]: give somebody the come-on (=do something to show you are sexually interested in someone)
example[14]: Rick’s the kind of guy who thinks every smile is a come-on.
